DANCE TOMORROW
Dances will be held as usual
after the St. -John's game tomorrow. The tea dance will
take place immediately after
the game; and the evening affair will be held from nine to
twelve. Both dances will take
place in the C. E. Hall.
Os Steinwald's orchestra
will furnish the music. Ticicets for the tea dance are fifty
cents, and one dollar for stag
or couple during the evening.
The dances will be under the
auspices of the Cotillon Club.

Dear Sirs:
About two years ago I bought a tin
of Edgeworth tobacco. I was so
pleased with its slow-smoking qualities
and wonderful aroma that I became
an Edgeworth enthusiast and have
smoked no other tobacco since,- although up to that time I think I can
truthfully say I had tried every wellknown British mixture and flake.
Moreover, I introduced one of the
other reporters to it. He in turn introduged another and he another until
finally it reached the News Editor.
There are now five of us all smoking
Edgeworth and enjoying it so much
that I thought you might like to have
this little appreciation of what, to
Britishers, is a comparatively unknown tobacco. I wish you every
success.
Yours faithfully,

Major Tipton
Speak
At A. S. M. E. Meeting
Major Tipton of the Maryland
National Guard will address the student branch of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at a
meeting on November 21 at 8:00
P. M. in room 110 M. E. Major
Tipton is at present one of the main
pilots for the Chesapeake Aircraft
Company and has been actively, engaged in flying since the war both
commercially and in his capacity as
Major in the National Guard. His
subject will be "Commercial Aviation." All students are invited to attend the meeting.

AMOCO-GAS, through superior
performance, is as well-known to the
motoring public as were the famous

At Next Assembly
Walter P. Swindel, Jr., coach of
the Barnstormers, will be the speaker at next week's assembly. "Pop"
is the successful director of all the
Barnstormers' productions, during
the last few years. He will give a
short address, but the subject ha's
not been definitely decided. It is
thought that he will have much to
say oncerning the Barnstormers of
'28. The later part of the assembly
will be turned into a "pep" meeting
for the Maryland game.

Dear Sirs:
About two years ago I bought a tin
of Edgeworth tobacco. I was so
pleased with its slow-smoking qualities
and wonderful aroma that I became
an Edgeworth enthusiast and have
smoked no other tobacco since,- although up to that time I think I can
truthfully say I had tried every wellknown British mixture and flake.
Moreover, I introduced one of the
other reporters to it. He in turn introduged another and he another until
finally it reached the News Editor.
There are now five of us all smoking
Edgeworth and enjoying it so much
that I thought you might like to have
this little appreciation of what, to
Britishers, is a comparatively unknown tobacco. I wish you every
success.
Yours faithfully,
'
(signed) David Moore

Major Tipton
Speak
At A. S. M. E. Meeting
Major Tipton of the Maryland
National Guard will address the student branch of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at a
meeting on November 21 at 8:00
P. M. in room 110 M. E. Major
Tipton is at present one of the main
pilots for the Chesapeake Aircraft
Company and has been actively, engaged in flying since the war both
commercially and in his capacity as
Major in the National Guard. His
subject will be "Commercial Aviation." All students are invited to attend the meeting.

"Pop"Swindell To Speak

Famous Asthe Four Horsemen
AMOCO-GAS, through superior
performance, is as well-known to the
motoring public as were the famous
Four Horsemen of Notre Dame in
the hey-day of their power.

At Next Assembly
Walter P. Swindel, Jr., coach of
the Barnstormers, will be the speaker at next week's assembly. "Pop"
is the successful director of all the
Barnstormers' productions, during
the last few years. He will give a
short address, but the subject ha's
not been definitely decided. It is
thought that he will have much to
say oncerning the Barnstormers of
'28. The later part of the assembly
will be turned into a "pep" meeting
for the Maryland game.

COSMOPOLITAN CLUB
HOLDS DANCE TONIGHT
A masquerade danee will be
held tonight from nine to
twelve at the C. E. Hall. It is
under the auspices of the Cosmopolitan Club of foreign students. Refreshments will be
served and prizes will be given
for the best costumes. The
music will be furnished by the
Hopkins Blue Jays. Tickets
are fifty cents per person.
